instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4: What is PM_SLP_S4? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S4_L When you see PM_SLP_S4, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S4_L.
definitions.ALL_SYSPWRGD: What is ALL_SYSPWRGD? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYSPWRGD, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
This arrived with no power and no liquid damage. Board looks pristine. Not sure what to check next.

<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 3.3V

<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 3.3V

<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> 3.4V

<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> 3.3V

<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>. -  3.43V

<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>. -  3.3V

<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>  -  3.43V

<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> 3.36V 

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Yes 3.4v on <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and SUS

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>, at same time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Yes, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> has a drop pulse

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Check <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>3_L</SIGNAL> for pulse (at same time).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: yes both  <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>3_L</SIGNAL> pulse

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Check for pulse at all big cois; at same time when trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.
Do the same for <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> too.

Just in case, try to start in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
back to this board

yes all big coils and <SIGNAL>ALL_SYSPWRGD</SIGNAL> has a quick pulse when triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Can you catch a pulse at <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> too?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: No pulse at  <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Check for pulse at pins 5, 6 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: pulse at pin 5 but no pulse at pin 6 & 3

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Tie together pins 5 & 6 and test again the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Still no power but there is a pulse at pins 6 and 3 now

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> pulsing now?

Try to start in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: All testing was performed with fan disconnected. When the fan is connected board now consistently powers up but fan spins very fast. Same with or without keyboard connected. only drawing .168 amps

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
If trackpad is not connected, the fan will spin with max speed.
Do you get CPU core voltage now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
CPU voltages still the same as before.

Without fan plugged in board only draws 0.76 amps but as soon as the fan is plugged in it goes up to 0.170 amps so still not fully booting.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
As I said, fan spins to max, if trackpad is not connected; or has a problem with its temp sensors.
Keyboard is not involved here.

<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> stays high now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> still 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Check <SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>CPU_VR_READY</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  1.050V

<SIGNAL>CPU_VR_READY</SIGNAL> 1.050V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Be sure <RESISTOR>R1962</RESISTOR> is good.
Remove <RESISTOR>R2071</RESISTOR>/81 and check <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>.
If still low, remove <CHIP>U2071</CHIP> and test it again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R1962</RESISTOR> is good

<RESISTOR>R2071</RESISTOR>/81 does not exist in boardview or schematic?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>. low with <CHIP>U2071</CHIP> removed

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: I hope you didn't check for "<RESISTOR>R2071</RESISTOR>/81"; there are two resistors, <RESISTOR>R2071</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R2081</RESISTOR>!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: When <RESISTOR>R2071</RESISTOR> is typed into <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board view no results are found

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
"[SIZE=7][B]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power"[/B][/SIZE]
Isn't this your thread title???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
yes but do not have board view for <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Thought 4924 is closest board view available for this board.

If you have correct board view can you share?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Here it comes...
[URL unfurl="true"]https://drive.google.com/file/d/19aZ0yIhyjP8nVC0GlRJQj6vHFXyDI9X-/view?usp=sharing[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> still 0v with  <RESISTOR>R2071</RESISTOR>/81 removed and <CHIP>U2071</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Then PCH has a problem.
Try heating it, to burn eventually accumulated crap underneath.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: No change after heating PCH with quality flux. To the donar pile it goes

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Just in case, check all voltages from page 11.
